title: 111_s3412
content: The "Public Transportation Preservation Act of 2010" acknowledges the financial struggles of transit systems and the impact on low-income workers, older Americans, and people with disabilities. Reduced service and higher fares can severely affect their quality of life. Millions of Americans rely on transit daily, and decreased service hinders job access and worsens traffic congestion. The Secretary of Transportation can provide grants for public transportation operating costs. Funds are apportioned with 80% according to section 5336, 10% according to section 5340, and 10% to other areas as per section 5311. The allocated amounts must be used for transportation purposes. The Secretary of Transportation can provide grants for public transportation operating costs to restore service, rescind fare increases, and prevent reductions through September 30, 2011, if due to funding decreases after January 1, 2009. Recipients can certify no major reductions to receive exceptions. The Secretary of Transportation can provide grants to prevent reductions in public transportation service or fare increases due to funding decreases. Recipients can use the funds to replace, rehabilitate, or repair existing transit capital assets. The Secretary of Transportation can provide grants to prevent reductions in public transportation service or fare increases by funding capital assets used in public transportation. Recipients must meet certain requirements and can receive up to 100 percent of the project's net cost. Applicable requirements of chapter 53 of title 49, United States Code, and Section 1101(b) of Public Law 109-59 apply to funding provided under this section. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,000,000,000 is authorized for this project, available until September 30, 2011. Funds must be expended by July 1, 2012. Oversight expenses are allocated at specific percentages and available until September 30, 2013.
